Facile and efficient synthesis of Pd2+@CN catalysts for enhanced phenol hydrogenation to cyclohexanone Jiuxuan Zhang Methodology Data curation Writing – original draft a Haipeng Zhao Data curation Validation a Liu Yang Writing – original draft Validation a Hong Jiang Investigation Supervision a Yan Du Supervision b ⁎ Rizhi Chen Conceptualization Supervision Writing – review & editing a ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing 211816, Jiangsu, PR China State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University Nanjing Jiangsu 211816 PR China State Key Laboratory of Materials-Oriented Chemical Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing, Jiangsu, P.R. China, 211816 b School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing 211816, Jiangsu, PR China School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Nanjing Tech University Nanjing Jiangsu 211816 PR China School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Nanjing Tech University, Nanjing, Jiangsu, P.R. China, 211816 ⁎ Corresponding authors. One-step phenol hydrogenation over Pd@N-doped carbon (CN) is a sustainable approach to produce cyclohexanone, a key intermediate in the production of nylon. In this work, cobalt sources and 2-methylimidazole (2-MeIm) were mixed and directly carbonized to synthesize CN materials. After acid etching and Pd loading, the Pd2+@CN catalysts were achieved, and the porous structures and surface properties can be modulated by tuning the kind of cobalt sources and the molar ratio of 2-MeIm and cobalt. The Pd2+@CN(D) (prepared by the direct carbonization strategy) demonstrates comparable performance in the phenol hydrogenation to the ZIF-67-derived Pd2+@CN(67), and more importantly, the obtained weight of Pd2+@CN(D) is 2.1 times higher than that of Pd2+@CN(67). The optimum Pd2+@CN-4 (synthesized with a molar ratio of 4 between 2-MeIm and cobalt acetate tetrahydrate) achieves superior and durable catalytic performance (a turnover frequency (TOF) of 125.9 h−1) for the well-developed hierarchically porous structures, rich defects and abundant alkaline. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Cyclohexanone Phenol hydrogenation Direct carbonization Green synthesis N-doped carbon Hierarchical pores Data Availability I have shared the link to my data/code at the Attach File step. 1 Introduction In recent decades, porous carbon matrixes have drawn extensive attention as functional supports for metal catalysts due to their chemical and physical stability and excellent mass/electronic transfer properties [1]. The surface chemistry of porous carbon matrixes can be altered through surface functionalization and decorating by heteroatoms (such as N, B, F, P, S, etc.) [2,3]. The incorporation of nitrogen in carbon matrixes makes the CN very attractive candidates as metal-free catalysts or supports for metals because of the favorably modified surface and bulk properties [4]. Nitrogen atoms in CN materials exist in the forms of pyridinic, graphitic, pyrrolic nitrogen, and nitrogen oxides, which can adsorb more substrates in suitable configuration and anchor metal nanoparticles (NPs) with high dispersion so as to intensify the catalytic performance [5,6]. However, the CN materials are usually prepared by the time-consuming and complicated template methods [7], and with underdeveloped porous structures [8]. To overcome the barriers, further exploration of simple and effective strategies to achieve CN materials with rich pores is highly desirable. Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) are a novel class of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), which are formed by coordination of metal ions (such as Zn, Co) and organic linkers (imidazole or its derivatives) [9]. In view of the large specific surface area, rich porous structure, easy functionalization, and abundant carbon and nitrogen species, ZIFs are excellent precursors for preparing porous CN materials [10]. Among them, ZIF-67 is an ideal and common precursor for the CN materials because of the self-doping of nitrogen, high yield, and low cost [11]. Xia et al. [12] synthesized a hollow skeleton composed of interlinked N-doped carbon nanotube frameworks (NCNTs) via using ZIF-67 as the exclusive precursor. In the process of pyrolysis, ZIF-67 not only provided C and N sources for the growth of NCNTs, but also served as the template for the hollow skeleton. The NCNTs showed excellent electrocatalytic activity due to the chemical composition and structure. In our previous works [13–17], CN materials were synthesized through one-step carbonization of ZIF-67, and after acid etching and Pd loading the Pd2+@CN catalysts were obtained. The influences of the synthesis conditions (solvents, metal sources, additional nitrogen sources) and the calcination conditions (temperature, atmosphere) of ZIFs on the morphology, surface properties, porous structure and the corresponding catalytic ability of Pd2+@CN were systematically investigated [14–17]. However, the synthesis of ZIFs often requires toxic and harmful organic solvents and the crystallization and after treatment processes are time-consuming, making the utilization of ZIFs and ZIF-derived materials environmentally unfriendly [18]. Furthermore, the mother liquid after crystallization is often waste, which contributes to the high cost of separation [19]. Therefore, it is urgent to explore novel methods that can obtain CN materials from precursors of ZIFs simply, efficiently and environmentally friendly. Due to the continuous interest in developing green strategies for preparing CN materials, in this work, the CN materials with rich mesoporous structures can be obtained through direct carbonization of the mixture of raw materials of ZIFs and the follow-up acid etching process. Unlike the synthesis of CN materials from ZIFs, the direct carbonization strategy effectively avoids the use of toxic solvents, the longstanding crystallization, and the separation of waste. Furthermore, the obtained weight of CN prepared via the direct carbonization strategy is more than 2.1 times higher than ZIF-67-derived CN (CN(67)) from the equivalent precursors. After Pd loading, the as-prepared Pd2+@CN and Pd2+@CN(67) catalysts reveal similar catalytic performance toward the selective hydrogenation of phenol to cyclohexanone owing to the analogous components, porous structures, and surface properties. The above mentioned results indicate that the environmentally friendly and time-saving direct carbonization strategy is very promising for the scale-up preparation of CN materials and practical applications from the point of green view. 2 Experimental The Pd2+@CN catalysts were fabricated via the following three steps as schematically illustrated in Fig. 1a: carbonization of mixed precursors, acid etching and Pd loading. The characterization of microstructures and catalytic performance evaluation were presented in the supporting information. 2.1 Carbonization 2-MeIm (50 mmol) and cobalt sources (6.25 mmol) were mixed via different ways, and then calcined in a tube furnace at an argon flow of 30 mL/min. The temperature rose from room temperature to 800 °C (5 °C/min), and then kept for 2 h. Based on our previous works [13,14,17], the calcination temperature has outstanding influence on the structure and catalytic performance of the Pd2+@CN catalysts. It was found in our previous work [13], when unreacted Co ions, imidazole linkers, and possible intermediate species in the mother liquid of ZIF-67 were recovered and then calcined at lower than 700 °C, the porous structures and surface properties of the corresponding CN materials were not suitable for the Pd loading and phenol hydrogenation. And, the optimal calcination temperature for the recovered unreacted Co ions, imidazole linkers and possible intermediate species (composition similar to the mixture of 2-MeIm and Co sources) was 800 °C. Therefore, in the present work, the calcination temperature was set at 800 °C. The optimal calcination temperature for the direct carbonization strategy will be investigated in the further work. The yielded black samples were marked as Co@CN(X), where X represents the mixing way of precursors, such as stirring (S), direct mixing (D), rotary evaporation (R) and grinding (G). The samples prepared with different cobalt sources were recorded as Co@CN-Y, where Y denotes the anion of cobalt sources, such as acetate (C), nitrate (N), sulfate (S) and chloride (Cl). The samples synthesized with different ratios of 2-MeIm and cobalt salts were named as Co@CN-x, where x is the molar ratio of 2-MeIm and cobalt salts. 2.2 Acid etching 0.4 g of Co@CN samples were added into 19.2 g of nitric acid aqueous solution (33.5 wt%), and then stirred at the temperature of 60 °C for 1 h. After acid etching, deionized water was used to entirely wash the samples, followed by drying at 70 °C for 4 h. The produced materials were denoted as CN. 2.3 Pd loading Loading Pd onto the CN carriers was performed through a wet impregnation strategy as follows. 0.01 g of Pd(OAc)2 and 0.2 g of CN were mixed together, and then 20 mL of acetone were added with continuous stirring at the temperature of 30 °C. After 12 h, rotary evaporation was applied to remove the liquid, followed by drying at 70 °C for 6 h. The yielded catalysts were marked as Pd2+@CN. The ZIF-67-derived Pd2+@CN(67) was prepared similar to Pd2+@CN except that 2-MeIm and cobalt sources were replaced by ZIF-67 (ZIF-67 was synthesized referring to the literature [13]). In the process of liquid phase hydrogenation of phenol, Pd2+ can be reduced to Pd0 in situ [20], thus the hydrogenation of phenol to cyclohexanone can be realized. Hence, no reduction steps were applied. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization The preparation process of Pd2+@CN through direct carbonization of raw materials of ZIFs is shown in Fig. 1a. The polyhedral ZIF-67 is obtained through crystallization (Fig. S1a, d), and as reported in literature [15], after carbonization and acid etching, ZIF-67 is converted to the carbon materials with metallic cobalt and with rough surface (Fig. S1). 2-MeIm can be transferred to carbon materials through the catalysis of the mixed cobalt sources during pyrolysis, and the decomposition components of 2-MeIm can reduce Co2+ into metal Co (Fig. S2). The Co@CN(X) samples all show rough and broken morphologies (Fig. S3). The partial removal of Co NPs by acid etching makes the characteristic peaks of carbon more conspicuous in the XRD patterns of CN(X), and the carbon layers protect some Co NPs from being etched out of Co@CN(X) (Figs. S2 and S4) [16]. The acid etching process has no obvious effect on the morphologies of CN(X) materials (Figs. S3 and S5). After Pd loading, the Pd2+@CN catalysts are obtained, and the obtained weight of Pd2+@CN(D) is 0.45 g from 50 mmol of 2-MeIm and 6.25 mmol of cobalt sources, which is 2.1 times higher than Pd2+@CN(67) from the equivalent precursors (Fig. 1b). The obvious difference should be caused by the preparation methods of CN materials. By the direct carbonization strategy, 2-MeIm can be directly transferred to CN materials through the catalysis of the mixed cobalt sources during pyrolysis followed by acid etching, and therefore higher weights of CN(D) and Pd2+@CN(D) can be obtained. For the latter, ZIF-67 is first produced through crystallization, and after carbonization and acid etching, CN(67) is obtained. The procedure of synthesizing ZIF-67 leads to significant loss of the precursors, and thus the obtained weights of CN(67) and Pd2+@CN(67) are low, similar to our previous work [13]. The higher obtained weight of Pd2+@CN(D) indicates that the direct carbonization strategy can promote the utilization of precursors of ZIFs. The Pd2+@CN catalysts all reveal similar XRD patterns with CN materials, and the characteristic peaks of Pd cannot be detected owing to its low loading amount or good dispersion (Fig. 1c, S4 and S6d) [21]. For the same metallic and organic precursors, Pd2+@CN(67) demonstrates similar crystal structure as Pd2+@CN(D) (Fig. 1c). Pd2+@CN(D) presents irregular broken morphology similar with CN(D) (Fig. 1d and S5b), while Pd2+@CN(67) inherits the polyhedral morphology from ZIF-67 owing to the stabilized framework (Fig. 1e and S1). The weak alkaline sites are detected in Pd2+@CN(D) and Pd2+@CN(67) (Fig. 1f), which may be derived from the N and C-rich 2-MeIm. The weak alkaline sites can adsorb phenol in the non-coplanar configuration, which is in favor of the selective hydrogenation to cyclohexanone [22]. The Pd2+@CN(X) samples all reveal type I and type IV N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms (Fig. 1g and S7a), which indicate that the Pd2+@CN(X) catalysts contain both micropores and mesopores [23]. The hierarchically porous structures of Pd2+@CN(X) can also be confirmed by the pore size distribution curves (Fig. 1h and S7b). The hierarchically porous structure of Pd2+@CN(67) is predictable due to the porous ZIF-67 precursor, and the similar results have been reported [14]. As previously reported in literature [13–15], the ZIF-67 derived catalysts usually have similar hierarchically porous structures, but there are some significant differences in the specific surface area and pore volume, which are affected by the ZIF-67 porous structure, calcination procedure, acid etching and Pd loading. The Pd2+@CN(X) samples not only demonstrate similar hierarchically porous structures (Fig. 1g and S7a) but also richer than ZIF-67-derived Pd2+@CN(67) (especially for the mesopores) (Table S1). The richer hierarchically porous structures of Pd2+@CN(X) may be generated by the following reasons: (a) the drastic volatilization of H2O and 2-MeIm strikes the carbon materials [24]; (b) the alkaline components formed by the decomposition of 2-MeIm etch the carbon materials [25]; (c) the aggregation of Co NPs during pyrolysis and removal of Co NPs by acid etching [14,26]. The interaction of 2-MeIm and Co in ZIF-67 is stronger than that in the mixtures (simply mixing 2-MeIm and Co together), so that the volatilization and decomposition of 2-MeIm in ZIF-67 is harder, and thus less pores are formed in the Pd2+@CN(67) catalyst. The Raman spectra of Pd2+@CN(D) and Pd2+@CN(67) display two bands (Fig. 1i), the D band (∼1350 cm–1) represents the defects in carbon and the G band (∼1600 cm–1) represents the graphitic carbon, and the ratio of the relative intensity of D band to G band (ID/IG) indicates the degree of structural defects [27]. Unlike Pd2+@CN(67) derived from ZIF-67 with ordered structures, Pd2+@CN(D) is prepared from disordered precursors, and thus the structure of Pd2+@CN(D) is more disordered than Pd2+@CN(67) (ID/IG 1.01 vs. 0.77) [28], indicating that Pd2+@CN(D) has more defects, in favor of loading Pd and high catalytic activity. According to the XPS results (Fig. S8), C, N, O, Co and Pd exist in Pd2+@CN(67) and Pd2+@CN(D), demonstrating that the catalysts are the Pd species loaded on the CN materials with remaining Co. Different form of nitrogen atoms in CN materials plays various roles [29], and thus the high-resolution N 1s spectra of Pd2+@CN(D) and Pd2+@CN(67) are investigated (Fig. 1j, k). The nitrogen atoms in Pd2+@CN(67) and Pd2+@CN(D) exist as pyridinic, pyrrolic, graphitic, and oxidized nitrogen, respectively [30]. Owing to the ordered structure, the content of graphitic-N in Pd2+@CN(67) is much higher than that of Pd2+@CN(D), meaning that the nitrogen atoms in Pd2+@CN(67) have higher degree of graphitization [31], which is in accordance with the Raman results (Fig. 1i). The composition results further confirm that the Pd2+@CN(X) and Pd2+@CN(67) catalysts are the Pd species loaded on the CN materials with residual Co (Table S2). The nitrogen content in Pd2+@CN(D) is higher than Pd2+@CN(67), contributing to its more alkaline sites (Fig. 1f) [32]. The well-developed porous structure, rich defects, abundant alkaline sites, and high obtained weight of Pd2+@CN(D) make it potential candidate in the field of catalysis equivalent as ZIF-derived catalysts [15]. To explore the mechanism of fixing and converting 2-MeIm via mixed cobalt sources to hierarchically porous CN materials during pyrolysis, the 2-MeIm, cobalt sources and their mixtures were heated (Figs. S9 and S10). The volatilization of 2-MeIm before 200 °C can be observed (Fig. S9). As reported, there will be no 2-MeIm left higher than 200 °C [13]. Due to the low melting point, the solid cobalt sources progressively liquefy before 180 °C. When the 2-MeIm and cobalt sources are placed together, they interact with each other at the interface, and the interaction leads to the quicker fusion of cobalt sources (Fig. S10). The interaction between 2-MeIm and cobalt sources and the low melting point of cobalt sources are in favor of the dissolution of 2-MeIm by molten cobalt, restraining the volatilization of 2-MeIm. Based on the above results, it may be speculated that cobalt in the liquid mixture catalyzes the decomposition and conversion of 2-MeIm to the carbon materials during pyrolysis. At the same time, the reductive decomposition components of 2-MeIm reduce Co2+ to metallic Co. The migration of Co NPs during pyrolysis, and the etching with gaseous H2O, 2-MeIm and basic components contribute to the CN materials with broken morphologies (Fig. 1d, S3, S5 and S6) and hierarchically porous structures (Fig. 1g and S7). Producing CN materials through direct carbonization of raw materials of ZIFs is simple, solvent-free and time-saving. The anions of metal sources have a marked impact on the catalytic performance of metal NPs [33], and thus they can have a great influence on the structures, morphologies, and surface properties of CN materials ( Figs. 1d, 2, S11-S15). As shown in Fig. S10, CoCl2·6H2O, CoSO4·7H2O and Co(C2H3O2)2·4H2O can also liquefy and dissolve 2-MeIm under low temperature, and thus they were also employed to synthesize CN materials via direct carbonization strategy. The Pd2+@CN-Y catalysts except Pd2+@CN-S all reveal typical peaks of carbon and metallic Co, indicating that 2-MeIm has been transformed to the carbon materials and cobalt ions have been reduced to Co NPs after pyrolysis (Fig. 2d and S11). Pd2+@CN-S demonstrates the peaks of the decomposition products of CoSO4·7H2O, indicating that the cobalt ions are hard to be transformed to metallic state in CoSO4·7H2O, and thus the 2-MeIm mixed with CoSO4·7H2O is difficult to be fixed and converted to carbon materials (Fig. S11). As previously reported, the protection of surrounding graphitic carbon leads to the residual of Co NPs [34], and the uniform Pd dispersion on CN-Y contributes to the similar crystal structures of Pd2+@CN-Y and CN-Y (Fig. 2d and S13) [14]. Due to the differences in charge, radius and interaction between anions and Co2+, the microscopic morphology of Pd2+@CN-Y is obviously different [33]. Pd2+@CN-S presents the morphology of block with some holes (Fig. 2b), and other Pd2+@CN-Y catalysts all show irregular broken morphologies (Figs. 1d, 2a and c). The difference in the morphology may be related with the catalysis function of Co in the 2-MeIm decomposition. Researchers have investigated the influences of the calcination conditions on the decomposition of ZIF materials, and confirmed that the Co species in ZIF-67 could intensify the decomposition of 2-MeIm [10,18]. Furthermore, in our previous work [13], the recovered wasted mother liquid of ZIF-67 (containing unreacted Co ions, imidazole linkers, and possible intermediate species) could be transformed to porous CN materials by direct pyrolysis. During pyrolysis, the reductive components formed by the 2-MeIm decomposition could reduce Co ions into Co NPs. And, the Co NPs with high activity could further catalyze the 2-MeIm decomposition to form CN materials with well-developed porous structures. The cobalt ions coupled with Cl-, NO3 - and C2H3O2 - can be reduced to Co NPs during pyrolysis (Fig. 2d and S11), and then the Co NPs can catalyze the 2-MeIm decomposition [10,13,18], thus the carbon block is destroyed in Pd2+@CN-Cl, N, C. The acid etching and Pd loading have little influence on the morphologies of carbon materials (Figs. 1d, 2, S12 and S14). The Raman spectra of Pd2+@CN-Y indicate that there are abundant defects in the Pd2+@CN-Y catalysts (Fig. S15), which are conducive to anchoring and dispersing active sites [35], thus improving the catalytic performance. The deep morphology characterization of Pd2+@CN-Y was performed by TEM ( Fig. 3). The Pd2+@CN-Y catalysts prepared from different cobalt sources have irregular bulk structures. The thickness of Pd2+@CN-Cl, Pd2+@CN-N and Pd2+@CN-C is thinner than Pd2+@CN-S, because the rapid volatilization of gas phase components break the bulk, which is consistent with the FESEM results (Figs. 1d and 2). Interestingly, Pd2+@CN-C displays the most broken morphology among Pd2+@CN-Y, possibly because the cobalt ions coupled with C2H3O2 - are easier to be reduced. C, N, O, Co, and Pd elements are uniformly distributed in all Pd2+@CN-Y catalysts ( Fig. 4), indicating that direct carbonization of 2-MeIm with different cobalt sources can produce CN materials, and the CN materials are suitable supports for Pd loading and dispersion. In addition, the Co NPs in Pd2+@CN-S are much more than other Pd2+@CN-Y catalysts, possibly because its thick bulk structure restricts the contact between acid and Co. N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms were obtained to investigate the porous structures of the Pd2+@CN-Y catalysts ( Fig. 5). The hysteresis loops in the isotherms of Pd2+@CN-Cl, Pd2+@CN-N and Pd2+@CN-C indicate the presence of mesoporous structures [36], and the rapid increase of N2 adsorption at relative low pressure manifests the microporous structures (Fig. 5a) [37], namely the three catalysts are hierarchically porous. There are little N2 adsorption on Pd2+@CN-S for its nonporous structure. The pore size distribution curves further verify the existence of mesopores in Pd2+@CN-Cl, Pd2+@CN-N and Pd2+@CN-C, and the almost nonporous structure of Pd2+@CN-S (Fig. 5b). The volatilization of uncoordinated 2-MeIm, etching with alkaline components, and migration and removal of Co NPs contribute to the development of hierarchically porous structures of the Pd2+@CN catalysts [13]. As shown in Table 1, Pd2+@CN-S has the smallest specific surface area and pore volume among the Pd2+@CN-Y catalysts due to its nonporous structure. The layered structure of Pd2+@CN-N (Fig. 3b) contributes to its highest specific surface area and pore volume. Pd2+@CN-Cl is thicker than Pd2+@CN-N and Pd2+@CN-C is more broken than Pd2+@CN-N (Fig. 3), and thus their specific surface areas and pore volumes are lower. Although the most broken morphology of Pd2+@CN-C leads to its relative low specific surface area, its mesopores are still retained during the carbonization process, thereby Pd2+@CN-C has the most proportion of mesopores (> 90 %). More mesopores are conducive to reducing the diffusion resistance of substrates, promoting the accessibility of active sites, thus improving the catalytic performance [38]. As shown in Table 2, the compositions of the Pd2+@CN-Y catalysts were studied by the CHN elemental analyzer and ICP. The Co content in Pd2+@CN-Y is in the order of Pd2+@CN-S > Pd2+@CN-N > Pd2+@CN-Cl > Pd2+@CN-C. Pd2+@CN-S has the most content of Co, because its thick bulk and dense structures restrict the interaction between Co and acid (Figs. 3c and 5a), in line with the elemental mapping results (Fig. 4). The most broken morphology of Pd2+@CN-C makes the Co NPs more accessible and it hard to retain nitrogen (Fig. 3d), resulting in its lowest Co and N contents. Because of the dense structure (Table 1), there are the lowest sites for anchoring Pd in Pd2+@CN-S (0.97 wt%) [14]. The highest specific surface area of Pd2+@CN-N contributes to its higher Pd content. The most proportion of mesopores in Pd2+@CN-C may be an important reason for its higher Pd content. The chemical compositions of the Pd2+@CN-Y catalysts and the state of elements were investigated by XPS ( Fig. 6 and S16). The C, N, O, Pd and Co elements are detected in all catalysts, indicating that the Pd2+@CN-Y catalysts are the Pd species loaded on the CN materials with remaining Co, which is consistent with the elemental mapping results (Fig. 4). The surface Pd contents in Pd2+@CN-Cl, Pd2+@CN-N and Pd2+@CN-C are similar, possibly because of the similar Pd loading and mesopores (Tables 1 and 2). The Pd loading in Pd2+@CN-S is the lowest among the Pd2+@CN-Y catalysts (Table 2), however, its surface Pd content is the highest. Pd2+@CN-S has a dense structure (Fig. 5, Table 1), and then most Pd species are loaded on its outside surface, resulting in the highest surface Pd content and the worst Pd dispersion. Absence of pre-reduction steps during the preparation of the Pd2+@CN catalysts, the Pd element is at the state of oxidation (Fig S17) [39]. The doping nitrogen in the CN materials has significant effect on the Pd2+@CN catalysts and different forms of nitrogen play various roles. Therefore, the high-resolution N 1s spectrum is studied in detail (Fig. 6). There are peaks at 398.4, 399.2, 400.5, 401.2 and 403.5 eV in all Pd2+@CN-Y catalysts, corresponding to pyridine-N, Co-N, pyrrole-N, graphitic-N and oxidized-N, respectively [30], signifying that the cobalt sources have no effect on the species of nitrogen. The relative contents of pyridine-N and pyrrorole-N in the catalysts prepared from four cobalt sources are basically the same. Pd2+@CN-S has the lowest content of graphitic-N, possibly because it is hard for the Co in cobalt sulfate heptahydrate to catalyze the conversion of 2-MeIm during the calcination process, which is in accordance with the XRD results (Fig. 2d and S11). Pd2+@CN-C has the highest relative content of graphitic-N, probably because the Co in cobalt acetate tetrahydrate can accelerate the transformation of 2-MeIm during pyrolysis (Fig. 2 and S11), which can be evidenced by the most broken morphology from another side (Fig. 3d). The high content of graphitic-N is conducive to the electron transport and improving the catalytic performance of the catalysts [40]. The pyrrole-N in the Pd2+@CN-Y catalysts can adsorb more substrates so as to improve the catalytic performance [41]. 3.2 Catalytic performance toward phenol hydrogenation One step hydrogenation of phenol to cyclohexanone is an environmentally friendly strategy [42], therefore it was employed as the model reaction to evaluate the performance of the Pd2+@CN catalysts. The obtained Co@CN and CN samples were also tested in the hydrogenation of phenol. Unfortunately, these samples do not exhibit catalytic ability in the hydrogenation of phenol under the used reaction conditions, in line with our previous works [13,14,17], confirming the significance of the Pd loading. Under the same reaction conditions, the Pd2+@CN catalysts prepared by different mixing methods almost display the same catalytic performance (Fig. S18a), because the Pd2+@CN(X) catalysts have similar microscopic morphologies, textural structures, compositions, and Pd contents (Fig. 1d, S6 and S7, Tables S1 and S2). Interestingly, the mixing method has significant influence on the obtained weight of Pd2+@CN(X). The obtained weight of Pd2+@CN(R) or Pd2+@CN(D) is almost twice over that of Pd2+@CN(G) or Pd2+@CN(S), and the remarkable difference might be ascribed to the following reasons. When mixing the Co source with 2-MeIm by grinding or stirring, the interaction between the two precursors makes the hydration water in the Co source quickly separate out. The rapid volatilization of water can accelerate the overflow of other volatile components, and thus the obtained weight of Pd2+@CN(G) or Pd2+@CN(S) is low. The hydration water might be partially removed by rotary evaporation, and it is slowly separated out when the two precursors are mixed directly. The slow release of water is helpful to the sluggish volatilization of organic components and thus more components can be converted to the CN materials, thereby higher obtained weights of Pd2+@CN(R) and Pd2+@CN(D) are achieved. Furthermore, the relative position of cobalt acetate tetrahydrate in the mixed raw materials has little influence on the catalytic performance and obtained weight of Pd2+@CN(D) (Fig. S18b). In addition, as compared to other mixing methods, the direct mixing method is simple and time-saving. Therefore, the direct mixing method was adopted for the following experiments including the influences of the kind of cobalt sources and the molar ratio of 2-MeIm and cobalt ( Fig. 7). The kind of cobalt sources almost has no influence on the cyclohexanone selectivity (Fig. 7a). The selectivity of cyclohexanone remains around 98 % over all the Pd2+@CN-Y catalysts, because the doping N in the Pd2+@CN-Y catalysts plays the role of alkaline sites that adsorb phenol in the configuration of non-coplanar (Figs. 1f and 6, Table 2), which is in favor of the production of cyclohexanone [22]. Interestingly, the kind of cobalt sources significantly affects the catalytic activity of the Pd2+@CN-Y catalysts. The Pd2+@CN-C catalyst prepared with cobalt acetate tetrahydrate as the cobalt source shows the best catalytic activity among Pd2+@CN-Y, with a phenol conversion of 76 % increased by about 32 times as compared to Pd2+@CN-S prepared with cobalt sulfate heptahydrate as the cobalt source. The superior catalytic activity of Pd2+@CN-C may be due to the following reasons: Pd2+@CN-C owns (a) the highest proportion of mesopores (Table 1) and the most broken morphology (Fig. 3d), which are conducive to the mass transfer and accessibility of active components [38]; (b) the highest actual loading of Pd (Table 2) with good dispersion (Fig. 4d), which can accelerate the dissociation of H2 and activate the substrates [43]; (c) the highest relative content of graphitic-N (Fig. 6d), which is in favor of the electron transport [41]. The possible reasons for the poorest catalytic activity of Pd2+@CN-S include: (a) the thickest bulk structure (Figs. 2b and 3c); (b) the smallest specific surface area and pore volume (Fig. 5, Table 1); (c) the lowest actual Pd loading (Table 2); (d) the lowest content of graphitic-N (Fig. 6c). In addition, the obtained weight of Pd2+@CN-Y also depends on the kind of cobalt sources. Pd2+@CN-S has the highest obtained weight owing to the better thermal stability of cobalt sulfate (Fig. S10). Similarly, Pd2+@CN-C owns higher obtained weight as compared to Pd2+@CN-Cl and Pd2+@CN-N. The above results confirm that cobalt acetate tetrahydrate is more suitable than other cobalt sources in the preparation of the Pd2+@CN catalysts via direct carbonization of the mixture of raw materials of ZIFs. In general, the molar ratio of organic ligands and metal sources has significant influence on the structures of ZIFs and ZIF-derived materials [44], thereby the effect of the molar ratio of 2-MeIm and cobalt on the microstructures and catalytic properties of the Pd2+@CN catalysts prepared with cobalt acetate tetrahydrate as the cobalt source was investigated. Based on the FESEM and XRD results, it can be declared that the molar ratio has little effect on the morphologies and crystal structures of the Co@CN-x, CN-x and Pd2+@CN-x samples (Figs. S19-S21). The detailed information given by the TEM images and Raman spectra show that more 2-MeIm are in favor of forming more broken CN materials with abundant defects (Figs. 3d, 4d and S22-S24). The well-developed mesoporous structures and higher Pd loading of the Pd2+@CN-x catalysts contribute to the efficient conversion of phenol (Fig. 7b and S25-S27, Tables S3 and S4), and the doping nitrogen guarantees the high cyclohexanone selectivity (Fig. S26, Table S4). When the molar ratio of 2-MeIm and Co is lower than 4, the N and pyrrole-N contents in Pd2+@CN-x increase with the molar ratio (Fig. S26, Table S4). The relative poor mesoporous structures (Table S3), fewer defects (Fig. S24), and lower N and pyrrole-N contents (Fig. S26, Table S4) lead to the lower catalytic abilities of Pd2+@CN-1 and Pd2+@CN-2. The Pd2+@CN-4, Pd2+@CN-8 and Pd2+@CN-12 catalysts perform almost the same in the selective hydrogenation of phenol (Fig. 7b), which is due to their similar compositions, porous structures, Pd loading and surface properties (Figs. S24-S27, Tables S3 and S4). It is worth noting that the obtained weight of Pd2+@CN-4 is the highest among Pd2+@CN-x (Fig. 7b). When the molar ratio of 2-MeIm and Co is higher than 4, the Co may be incompetent to fix and convert so much 2-MeIm to the CN materials. As the molar ratio of 2-MeIm and Co is lower than 4, although the Co can catalyze 2-MeIm to the CN materials, there are more Co NPs in Co@CN that can be etched out during the acid etching process, leading to the decreased obtained weight with the decrease in the molar ratio. The above results indicate that the most appropriate molar ratio of 2-MeIm and cobalt acetate tetrahydrate is 4, and the as-prepared Pd2+@CN-4 catalyst has high catalytic performance and obtained weight. The reaction temperature and time for the phenol hydrogenation over Pd2+@CN-4 were further optimized. As shown in Fig. 7c, the phenol conversion increases with the reaction temperature, because higher temperature can accelerate the interaction between active components and substrates [45]. When the temperature rises to 100 °C, the phenol conversion climbs to the highest value. With further increasing the temperature, the phenol conversion remains but the cyclohexanone selectivity decreases owing to the deep hydrogenation [46], and the deep hydrogenation product is identified as cyclohexanol according to the GC-MS result of the reaction mixture (Fig. S28). Similarly, the phenol conversion increases with prolonging the reaction time, and the phenol conversion is 99 % and the cyclohexanone selectivity is 94 % at the reaction time of 30 min (Fig. 7d). Further prolonging the reaction time leads to excessive hydrogenation of cyclohexanone, decreasing the selectivity [47]. The catalytic stability of a catalyst is another important index to evaluate the performance of the catalyst [48]. To make the cycling experiments results more convinced, the phenol conversion over Pd2+@CN-4 was controlled at about 90 %. As shown in Fig. 8a, in the initial three cycles, the conversion of phenol increases from 93 % to 99 %, because partial Pd2+ species in Pd2+@CN-4 have been in-situ reduced to Pd0 during the hydrogenation reaction (Fig. S28b) [49], and the electron-rich Pd0 can activate H2 quickly than Pd2+ and then improve the catalytic activity [50]. In the subsequent cycling experiments, due to the slight mass loss of Pd2+@CN-4 in the recovery process, the conversion of phenol decreases slightly. The crystal structure, morphology and composition of the recycled Pd2+@CN-4 catalyst almost keep unchanged (Fig. 8b-d and S21). ICP results show that no Pd and Co leaching occurs during the cycling experiments. The results indicate that the Pd2+@CN-4 catalyst has good catalytic stability in the phenol hydrogenation. In order to further demonstrate the superiority of producing the Pd2+@CN catalysts through direct carbonization of precursors of ZIFs, the TOF values of the catalysts prepared in this work, ZIF-derived catalysts and other Pd-based catalysts applied to the phenol hydrogenation reported in literature were compared ( Table 3). As can be seen, Pd2+@CN(D) reveals higher catalytic ability than Pd2+@CN(67) on account of its well-developed porous structure, rich defects and abundant alkaline sites (Fig. 1f–k, Tables S1 and S2). Pd2+@CN-C has higher mesopore proportion and graphitic-N content than Pd2+@CN(D) (Fig. 6, Table 1), and more mesopores are conducive to reducing the mass transfer resistance [38] and more graphitic-N are in favor of accelerating the electron transport [41], so that Pd2+@CN-C performs better than Pd2+@CN(D) in the phenol hydrogenation. Pd2+@CN-4 displays a TOF value surpassing the catalytic performance of most of previously reported Pd-based catalysts (especially ZIF-derived catalysts) under similar reaction conditions. Pd@CN(1:3)− 650 and Pd@CN-H reported in literature perform better than Pd2+@CN-4 due to their unique structures (two-dimensional morphology for Pd@CN(1:3)-650 [51], and hierarchically porous CN composed of CNTs and a porous carbon framework for Pd@CN-H [15]). However, the unique structures require the synthesis of ZIFs and elaborate pyrolysis processes. Considering the time-saving, solvent-free and high obtained weight, the direct carbonization strategy is competitive compared with the strategies based on ZIFs. 4 Conclusions A green strategy, i.e. the direct carbonization of mixed precursors of ZIFs, was developed for producing the CN materials with high utilization of precursors. Following by acid etching and Pd loading, a series of Pd2+@CN catalysts with hierarchically porous structures were obtained. The mixing way of 2-MeIm and Co sources, kind of cobalt sources, and molar ratio of 2-MeIm and Co significantly affect the microstructures, surface properties, obtained weights and catalytic performance of the Pd2+@CN catalysts. As cobalt acetate tetrahydrate with 4 times of 2-MeIm were directly mixed and carbonized, the Pd2+@CN-4 catalyst with plentiful mesoporous structures, rich defects, increased N amount and Pd loading, and high obtained weight is achieved. Pd2+@CN-4 demonstrates superior catalytic performance toward the selective phenol hydrogenation, with a phenol conversion of 99 %, a cyclohexanone selectivity of 94 %, and a TOF value of 125.9 h−1 higher than most of Pd-based catalysts. These findings indicate that the direct carbonization approach of the precursors of ZIFs is highly efficient and environmentally friendly, which can offer a green strategy for producing the CN materials. coredata.dc:description: One-step phenol hydrogenation over Pd@N-doped carbon (CN) is a sustainable approach to produce cyclohexanone, a key intermediate in the production of nylon. In this work, cobalt sources and 2-methylimidazole (2-MeIm) were mixed and directly carbonized to synthesize CN materials. After acid etching and Pd loading, the Pd2+@CN catalysts were achieved, and the porous structures and surface properties can be modulated by tuning the kind of cobalt sources and the molar ratio of 2-MeIm and cobalt. The Pd2+@CN(D) (prepared by the direct carbonization strategy) demonstrates comparable performance in the phenol hydrogenation to the ZIF-67-derived Pd2+@CN(67), and more importantly, the obtained weight of Pd2+@CN(D) is 2.1 times higher than that of Pd2+@CN(67). The optimum Pd2+@CN-4 (synthesized with a molar ratio of 4 between 2-MeIm and cobalt acetate tetrahydrate) achieves superior and durable catalytic performance (a turnover frequency (TOF) of 125.9 h−1) for the well-developed hierarchically porous structures, rich defects and abundant alkaline.
coredata.dc:title: Facile and efficient synthesis of Pd2+@CN catalysts for enhanced phenol hydrogenation to cyclohexanone
